title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.11.15 | 06-07-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.text: Nama Om Vishnupadaya Krishna Preshtaya Bhutale
Shreemate Bhaktivedanta Swamin Nithinamine
Namaste Saraswate Deve Gauravani Pracharine
Nirvishesha Shunyavadi Pashchatyade Shatarine
Om Agyanati Mirandhasya Gyanan Janashalakaya
Chaksharon Militam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
Jaya Shri Krishna Chaitanya Prabhu Nithyananda
Shri Advaita Gadadhara Shiva Sadhi Gauravakta Vrinda
Hare Krishna Hare Krishna Krishna Krishna Hare Hare
Hare Rama Hare Rama Rama Rama Hare Hare
Om Namo Bhagavate Vasudevaya
Narayanam Namaskritya Naram Chaivanarottamam
Devi Saraswati Vyasam Tato Jayam Udi Raye
In this session we will be discussing from the 15th verse of the 11th chapter of the 1st canto of Shreemad Bhagavata.
Dwarid Dwarigrahanamcha Dadhi Akshata Palekshubhihi
Alankratam Purnakumbhair Balibhir Dhupadipakaihi
Further description of the decorations.
Translation.
Translation of this verse.
In each and every door of the residential houses, auspicious things like curd, unbroken fruits, sugar cane and full water pots with articles for worship, incense and candles were all displayed.
So, it's a festive atmosphere just because Krishna has arrived in Dwaraka.
It's a festival.
Receiving the Lord.
And everyone is alert to receive the Lord appropriately.
Every house, all the doors of every residential house, auspicious things are used to decorate the door, the entrance, unbroken fruits, pots filled with sugar.
Every house, all the doors of every residential house, auspicious things are used to decorate the door, the entrance, unbroken fruits, pots filled with sugar.
Every house, all the doors of every residential house, auspicious things are used to decorate the door, the entrance, unbroken fruits, pots filled with sugar.
Every house, all the doors of every residential house, auspicious things are used to decorate the door, the entrance, unbroken fruits, pots filled with sugar.
Every house, all the doors of every residential house, auspicious things are used to decorate the door, the entrance, unbroken fruits, pots filled with sugar.
Every house, all the doors of every residential house, auspicious things are used to decorate the door, the entrance, unbroken fruits, pots filled with sugar.
Every house, all the doors of every residential house, auspicious things are used to decorate the door, the entrance, unbroken fruits, pots filled with sugar.
and sugar cane and incense candles for worship all to receive the lord appropriately
so sri la prabhupada says a very important point here in the purport the process of reception
according to vedic rites is not at all dry the reception was made not simply by decorating the
roads and streets as above mentioned but by worshiping the lord with requisite ingredients
like incense lamps flowers sweets fruits and other palatable eatables according to one's capacity
you see so worship of the lord is the center
point in all these decorations all the arrangements worship of the lord
so the
vishnu purana says the entire varnashrama dharma aims at worship of vishnu by all the members
of this society irrespective of which classification they belong
the worship of the lord vishnu is the goal of practicing varnashrama dharma
and only by worship of vishnu the supreme lord can we perfect our life can we prepare ourselves
to get ultimate liberation and go back home back to godhead so that was clearly demonstrated by the
supreme lord vishnu
these devotees of Dwaraka how they received the Lord and how they worshipped
him so Srila Prabhupada further says all were offered to the Lord everything that
they were using for decorating and the items they had kept ready to receive the
Lord they were used to not only decorate but also to offer to the Lord like
incense lamps fruits and edibles different eatables and the remnants of
foodstuff are distributed amongst the gathering citizens so it was not like a
dry reception of these modern days modern days they have reception for some
important personalities or leaders but there is no distribution of foodstuff
there's no worship of the Lord
that is missing that is lacking each and every house was ready to receive the
Lord in a similar way and thus each and every house on the roads and streets
distributed such remnants of food to the citizens and therefore the festival was
successful without distribution of food no function is complete and that is the
way of Vedic tradition
Vedic culture this is the Vedic culture that Vedic culture means worship of the
Lord and the remnants are distributed to the people who participate in this
festival so it's not a dry reception or dry festival no so Prabhupada says no
function is complete in the Vedic culture
without distribution of food. Regarding distribution of food, in the Bhagavad Gita, Krishna explains
in the third chapter, thirteenth verse, yajna shishta asinaha santaha mucchante sarva-kilbhishaihi
bunjate tetu agham paapa ye pachanti atmakaranat. Very important verse, where Krishna describes
in this third chapter of the Bhagavad Gita, that devotees of the Lord are released from
all kinds of sins, because they eat food which is offered first for sacrifice. Yajna is sacrifice,
yajna shishta is remnants of food offered for yajna. Others who prepare food for personal
sense enjoyment, verily eat only sin.
Krishna says this in the Bhagavad Gita. Bunjate means they eat. Who? Agham paapa, huge quantities
of sin. Who are they? Ye pachanti, those who prepare food, atmakaranat, for their own sense
enjoyment. There is no offering made to the Supreme Lord. So, nowadays you can see, most
people, they simply either purchase something, or they buy something, or they buy something,
or they buy something, or they buy something, or they buy something, or they buy something,
or they buy something, or they buy something, or they buy something, or they buy something,
or they buy something, or they buy something, or they buy something, or they buy something,
some ready-made food, and eat it, or they prepare something at home that is also simply
prepared and eaten. They do not know that they have to worship the Lord and offer him
foodstuff, and only accept remnants of food. So, what is wrong if simply somebody eats
without offering to the Lord? It is explained in this verse of the Bhagavad Gita, if they
eat food which is not offered to Krishna, then they are eating sin.
Our taking birth itself in this material world is because of our past sinful activities.
So we already are carrying a load of sinful reactions from our past life or past lives.
Now adding to that more sinful reactions by not offering food and simply consuming food,
not offering food is only going to increase our suffering in this world.
Regarding the type of food that should be offered to Krishna,
Krishna accepts only food which is in the mode of goodness.
So what is food in the mode of goodness?
It is described in the 17th chapter, 8th verse.
āyuḥ sattva balārogyaḥ sukhaḥ prīti vyavardhanāḥ
rasyaḥ snigdhāḥ sthirāḥ hṛdyāḥ āhārāḥ sātvikaḥ priyāḥ
That which is in the mode of goodness, food is in the mode of goodness,
increase the duration of life, āyuḥ.
Purify one's existence, sattva.
Bala, they give strength.
ārogyaḥ, they promote good health.
Sukhaḥ means they give happiness.
And prīti vyavardhanāḥ and they give satisfaction.
And further characteristics of such food,
such nourishing foods are sweet, juicy, fattening and palatable.
So unless food is palatable, unless food is of this characteristic,
it is not in the mode of goodness.
Typically, food in the mode of passion is very, very pungent, extremely spicy.
Excess of spice is used or excess of salt or excess of sourness,
chili, like that.
And food in the mode of ignorance is completely decomposing and stale.
And that which is untouchable, in the Vedic language,
untouchable is that which is stool and flesh, animal flesh, animal eggs,
animal remains.
So these are all untouchables.
So that is food in the mode of ignorance.
So when we are to offer food, we should remember,
we should offer food only that is in the mode of goodness.
And further, regarding sacrifice, Krishna says in the 17th chapter, 13th verse,
The meaning of this verse is,
That sacrifice performed in defiance of scriptural injunctions,
in which no spiritual food is distributed,
no hymns are chanted,
and no remunerations are made to the priests,
and which is faithless,
that sacrifice is of the nature of ignorance.
So merely doing a sacrifice is not enough.
The sacrifice has to be performed in the mode of goodness.
So the characteristic of Tamsik sacrifice,
or sacrifice in the mode of ignorance is,
food is not distributed.
As opposed to this,
what was described in this 15th verse,
in the description of Dwaraka Dham,
how they received Krishna,
they worshipped Krishna,
they offered night foodstuffs to him,
and the remnants were distributed among the people.
Even when Prabhupada established his Kaun,
temples,
he always said,
Prasadam distribution should be there.
Prasadam distribution should be there.
So it's the Vedic culture,
the temple's food is offered to the deity,
who is worshipped,
Krishna or Vishnu deity,
and the remnants are distributed among the temple visitors.
This is the Vedic culture.
Prasadam distribution.
Prasadam distribution is also important in Kali Yuga
because people can purify their heart of sinful reactions
simply by taking Prasadam,
Krishna Prasadam.
And not only it purifies their heart of sinful reactions,
but it also awakens their dormant devotion.
Prasadam is completely satisfying to the tongue
and even to the mind.
Prasadam nourishes the body very nicely.
So such Krishna Prasadam should be offered,
nice preparation should be offered,
palatable, sweet, juicy, nourishing.
Foods in the mode of goodness should be offered to Krishna
and the remnants should be distributed.
Only then will people easily become Krishna conscious.
They will progress on the path of bhakti
and they will be able to actually make spiritual advancement,
develop all good qualities
that are to be found in devatas.
Asyasthi bhakti bhagavati akinchana sarvair gunaistatra samasate suraha
All good qualities are to be found in those
who engage in pure devotional service
and develop all divine qualities.
I will stop here.
Thank you very much.
Hare Krishna.
